<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Revenue
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, our revenue decreased by $30.5&nbsp;million, or 1.7%, to $1,808.9&nbsp;million,
	compared to $1,839.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Included in revenue was a decrease of approximately $25.4&nbsp;million from the impact of foreign currency
	translation caused by the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar versus the Japanese Yen, Russian Ruble and other currencies, and an increase of approximately $2.9&nbsp;million attributable to recent
	acquisitions and divestitures. Excluding the effects of foreign currency translation and our recent acquisitions and divestitures, revenue decreased by $8.0&nbsp;million, or 0.4%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	48
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=49,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=422835,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DO74301A.;8',USER='CHE107322',CD='25-FEB-2016;22:32' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO74301_1_49">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BSI
	Segment revenue decreased by $34.9&nbsp;million, or 2.0%, to $1,674.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $1,709.5&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. BEST Segment revenue increased by $5.5&nbsp;million, or 3.7%, to $152.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $147.4&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Please
	see the Segment Results section later in this section for additional discussion of our revenue.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gross Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our gross profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $763.3&nbsp;million, resulting in a gross profit margin of 42.2%,
	compared to $805.2&nbsp;million, resulting in a gross profit margin of 43.8%, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Included in gross profit were various charges for amortization of
	acquisition-related intangible assets and other acquisition-related costs and restructuring costs totaling $44.4&nbsp;million and $27.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	and 2013, respectively. Excluding these charges, our gross profit margin for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013 was 44.7% and 45.3%, respectively. The lower gross profit margin was
	primarily driven by the negative effects of foreign currency translation rates, including the impact of the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar versus the Japanese Yen, as our Yen denominated revenues
	substantially exceeded our Yen denominated expenses. In addition, 2013 gross profit margin benefited from license revenue recognized on the sale of technology in the BEST Segment, which had no cost of
	revenue. These effects were partially offset by favorable changes in the mix of products sold during 2014, including a 21 Tesla high-field magnet that benefited from higher gross profit margins.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Selling, General and Administrative
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our selling, general and administrative expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased to $451.0&nbsp;million, or
	24.9% of revenue, from $437.9&nbsp;million, or 23.8% of revenue, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in selling, general and administrative expenses was primarily attributable
	to: increased sales and marketing spending, particularly in our former LSC Division for our MALDI Biotyper product; the hiring of new senior management; general and administrative spending related to
	certain investments including financial reporting system improvements and strategic advisory services; higher allowance for doubtful accounts including amounts associated with certain distributor
	arrangements in Asia; and expenses relating to recent acquisitions. The increases were partially offset by the favorable impact of changes in foreign currency translation rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Research and Development
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our research and development expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 decreased to $174.2&nbsp;million, or 9.6% of
	revenue, from $190.5&nbsp;million, or 10.4% of revenue, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The decrease in research and development expenses was attributable to our efforts to improve the
	efficiency of our product development process.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Impairment of Assets
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded an impairment charge of $11.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, comprising
	definite-lived intangible asset and other long-lived assets of $0.9&nbsp;million and $5.5&nbsp;million, respectively, relating to our former CAM Division caused by restructuring and divestiture
	actions, and an impairment charge of $5.1&nbsp;million within our BEST Segment to reduce the carrying value of certain long-lived assets to their fair value caused by the projected cash flows of
	those assets not expected to be sufficient to recover their carrying value.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, the Company performed its annual goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible impairment evaluation by performing a qualitative assessment and concluded
	that it is
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	49
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=50,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=202885,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DO74301A.;8',USER='CHE107322',CD='25-FEB-2016;22:32' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO74301_1_50">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	more-likely-than-not
	that the fair value of the reporting units are greater than their carrying amount, and therefore, no additional impairment is required.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No
	impairment losses were recorded related to definite-lived intangible assets during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Other Charges, Net
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other charges, net of $21.2&nbsp;million recorded in 2014 related to the BSI Segment. The charges consisted of $11.1&nbsp;million
	of restructuring costs related to closing facilities and implementing outsourcing and other restructuring initiatives, $3.2&nbsp;million of legal and other professional service fees associated with
	our internal investigation and review of our operations in China, $2.9&nbsp;million of acquisition-related costs and $4.0&nbsp;million of costs associated with the initial stages of a global IT
	transformation initiative.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	charges, net of $28.6&nbsp;million recorded in 2013 related primarily to the BSI Segment. The charges consist of $18.2&nbsp;million of restructuring costs, including
	$15.9&nbsp;million within the BSI Segment and $2.3&nbsp;million within the BEST Segment, related to closing facilities and implementing outsourcing and other restructuring initiatives,
	$6.1&nbsp;million of legal and other professional service fees associated with our internal investigation and review of our operations in China, $3.6&nbsp;million of acquisition-related costs and
	$0.7&nbsp;million related to two factory relocations within the BEST Segment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Operating Income
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $105.4&nbsp;million, resulting in an operating margin of 5.8%,
	compared to income from operations of $148.2&nbsp;million, resulting in an operating margin of 8.1% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Operating income included restructuring costs of
	$36.1&nbsp;million and $25.3&nbsp;million during the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, related to closing facilities and implementing outsourcing and other restructuring initiatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
	income also included $42.9&nbsp;million and $32.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, for various charges for amortization of
	acquisition-related intangible assets and other acquisition-related costs, legal and other professional service fees related to our internal investigation and review of our operations in China,
	impairment of long-lived assets and costs associated with a global information technology transformation initiative. Excluding the charges noted above, operating margins were 10.2% and 11.2% for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively. The decline in operating margin was driven by the negative effect caused by changes in foreign currency translation rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Interest and Other Income (Expense), Net
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest and other income (expense), net during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was ($4.1) million, compared to ($23.6) million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the major components within interest and other income (expense), net were net interest expense of $12.5&nbsp;million, a settlement
	charge related to the review of our operations in China of $2.4&nbsp;million and realized and unrealized losses on foreign currency transactions of $2.0&nbsp;million. These expenses were partially
	offset by gains on the sale of product lines of $8.3&nbsp;million driven by the divestiture of product lines within the former CAM Division noted above, an insurance claim reimbursement of
	$2.5&nbsp;million, and an incentive from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts of $1.1&nbsp;million. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the major components within interest and other
	income (expense), net were net interest expense of $12.4&nbsp;million and realized and unrealized losses on foreign currency transactions of $10.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	50
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=51,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=136788,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DO74301A.;8',USER='CHE107322',CD='25-FEB-2016;22:32' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO74301_1_51">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Provision for Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The income tax provision for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $41.7&nbsp;million compared to an income tax provision of
	$42.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, representing effective tax rates of 41.2% and 34.3%, respectively. The increase in the effective tax rate is primarily caused by
	unbenefited losses associated with the actions at our former CAM Division. That impact was offset slightly by changes in the mix of earnings among tax jurisdictions. Our income tax provision for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013 reflects amounts for non-U.S. entities only as we maintained a full valuation allowance against all U.S. deferred tax assets, including our U.S. net
	operating losses and tax credits, until evidence existed that it is more likely than not that the loss carryforward and credit amounts will be utilized to offset U.S. taxable income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Income Attributable to Noncontrolling Interests
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $2.9&nbsp;million compared to
	$1.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The net income attributable to noncontrolling interests represents the minority shareholders' proportionate share of the net income
	recorded by our majority-owned indirect subsidiaries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Income Attributable to Bruker Corporation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our net income attributable to Bruker Corporation for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $56.7&nbsp;million, or $0.33 per
	diluted share, compared to net income of $80.1&nbsp;million, or $0.48 per diluted share, for 2013. The decrease for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was primarily caused by lower gross margin
	levels and a higher effective tax rate, partially offset by gains on the sale of product lines in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_15"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Segment Results
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->

</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013 (dollars in millions):
</FONT>
</P>

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(a)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	product and service revenue between reportable segments.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	BSI Segment Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BSI Segment revenue decreased by $34.9&nbsp;million, or 2.0%, to $1,674.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	compared to $1,709.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Included in revenue was a decrease of approximately $25.5&nbsp;million from the impact of foreign currency
	translation caused by the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar versus the Japanese Yen, Russian Ruble and other currencies, and an increase of approximately $2.9&nbsp;million attributable to recent
	acquisitions and divestitures. Excluding the effects of foreign currency translation and our recent acquisitions and divestitures, revenue decreased by $12.3&nbsp;million, or 0.7%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	51
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=52,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=558171,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DO74301A.;8',USER='CHE107322',CD='25-FEB-2016;22:32' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO74301_1_52">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bruker
	BioSpin Group revenue decreased $1.6&nbsp;million, or 0.3%, to $622.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $624.4&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Bruker BioSpin Group revenue reflected lower sales caused by reduced orders of NMR systems from governmental and academic research customers, partially offset by the
	recognition of revenue on the sale of a 21 Tesla high-field magnet and higher sales of MRI, MI and EPR products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bruker
	CALID Group revenue decreased by $27.9&nbsp;million, or 4.8%, to $553.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $581.4&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The decrease in revenue was driven by declines in the former CAM Division, in part due to the divestiture and restructuring actions during the third and fourth
	quarters of 2014, and delays in obtaining export licenses related to certain CBRNE orders. These declines were partially offset by increased sales of the MALDI Biotyper and MIR and NIR product lines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bruker
	Nano Group revenue decreased by $5.4&nbsp;million, or 1.1%, to $498.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $503.7&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The principal drivers of this decline were: continued weakness in end market demand for semiconductor, data storage and microelectronics products; the pricing advantage
	our Japanese based competitors have resulting from the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar and Euro against the Japanese Yen; and reduced demand from customers in Russia as a result of the geopolitical
	uncertainty in the region. These declines were partially offset by revenue generated from the recently acquired line of fluorescence microscopy products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;System
	revenue and aftermarket revenue as a percentage of total BSI Segment revenue were as follows during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013 (dollars in millions):
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_16"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:80%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">

</FONT>
</P>

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;System
	revenue in the BSI Segment includes nuclear magnetic resonance systems, magnetic resonance imaging systems, electron paramagnetic imaging systems, mass spectrometry systems, gas
	chromatography systems, CBRNE detection systems, X-ray systems, spark-optical emission spectroscopy systems, atomic force microscopy systems, stylus and optical metrology systems, molecular
	spectroscopy systems, fluorescent microscopy and other systems. Aftermarket revenues in the BSI Segment include accessory sales, consumables, training and services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	BEST Segment Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BEST Segment revenue increased by $5.5&nbsp;million, or 3.7%, to $152.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	compared to $147.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in revenue was primarily attributable to higher sales of cavity devices, which more than offset the 2013
	license revenue recognized on the sale of technology.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	52
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;System
	and wire revenue and aftermarket revenue as a percentage of total BEST Segment revenue were as follows during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013 (dollars in
	millions):
</FONT>

<FONT SIZE=1>
<B>
	2014
</B>
</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&#8203;
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&#8203;
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_GRID,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;" -->
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&#8203;
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_GRID,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;" -->
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&#8203;
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;System
	and wire revenue in the BEST Segment includes low and high temperature superconducting wire and superconducting devices, including magnets, linear accelerators and radio frequency
	cavities. Aftermarket revenues in the BEST Segment consist primarily of license revenue and consumables sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gross Profit and Operating Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, gross profit margin in the BSI Segment decreased to 43.7% from 45.3% in the comparable
	period in 2013. Lower gross profit margins resulted primarily from restructuring charges recorded during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 related to closing facilities and implementing
	outsourcing and other restructuring initiatives, and the negative effect of foreign currency translation rates, including the impact of the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar versus the Japanese Yen.
	These declines were partially offset by an increase caused by changes in the mix of products sold, including a 21 Tesla high-field magnet that benefited from higher gross margins.
	The BEST Segment gross profit margin decreased to 18.8% from 21.5% for the comparable period in 2013. Lower gross margins resulted primarily from license revenue recognized in 2013 on the sale of
	technology which had no cost of revenue.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, selling, general and administrative expenses and research and development expenses in the BSI Segment decreased to $604.8&nbsp;million, or
	36.1% of segment revenue, from $609.1&nbsp;million, or 35.6% of segment revenue, for the comparable period in 2013. The decrease in dollars reflects lower research and development expense
	attributable to our efforts to improve the efficiency of our product development process. This decrease was offset by: higher sales and marketing spending, particularly for our MALDI Biotyper product;
	the hiring of new senior management; general and administrative spending related to certain investments including financial reporting system improvement and strategic advisory services; higher
	allowance for doubtful accounts including amounts associated with certain distributor arrangements in Asia; and expenses caused by recent acquisitions. These increases were partially offset by the
	effect of changes in foreign currency translation rates. The increase as a percentage of revenue was caused by lower revenue levels in 2014. Selling, general and administrative expenses and research
	and development expenses in the BEST Segment remained relatively consistent at $20.4&nbsp;million, or 13.3% of segment revenue, in 2014 compared to $19.3&nbsp;million, or 13.1% of segment revenue,
	in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	53
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(a)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	corporate costs and eliminations not allocated to the reportable segments.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BSI
	operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $99.8&nbsp;million, resulting in an operating margin of 6.0%, compared to income from operations of
	$138.9&nbsp;million, resulting in an operating margin of 8.1%, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Income from operations included $73.7&nbsp;million and $54.1&nbsp;million in the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, of various charges representing amortization of acquisition-related intangible assets and other acquisition-related costs, legal and other
	professional fees related to our internal investigation and review of our operations in China, restructuring and relocation costs, impairment of definite-lived intangible assets and other long-lived
	assets and costs associated with a global IT transformation initiative. Excluding these costs, operating income for BSI was $173.5&nbsp;million and $193.0&nbsp;million, resulting in operating
	margins of 10.4% and 11.3%, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. Operating income, excluding these costs, decreased as a result of the negative effect of changes in
	foreign currency translation rates,
	including the impact the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar versus the Japanese Yen as our Yen denominated revenues substantially exceeded our Yen denominated expenses, lower gross margin levels and an
	increase in selling, general and administrative expenses. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in research and development expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BEST
	operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $3.4&nbsp;million, resulting in an operating margin of 2.2%, compared to operating income of $9.5&nbsp;million,
	resulting in an operating margin of 6.4%, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The decline in operating margin was the result of license revenue recognized in 2013 on the sale of technology
	which had no cost of revenue that did not recur, and impairment charges of $5.1&nbsp;million recorded in 2014 to reduce the carrying value of certain long-lived assets to their estimated fair value.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We currently anticipate that our existing cash and credit facilities will be sufficient to support our operating and investing needs
	for at least the next twelve months. Our future cash requirements could be affected by acquisitions that we may make, repurchases of our common stock, or the payment of dividends in the future.
	Historically, we have financed our growth and liquidity needs through cash flow generation and a combination of debt financings and issuances of common stock. In the future, there are no assurances
	that additional financing alternatives will be available to us, if required, or if available, will be obtained on terms favorable to us.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net cash provided by operating activities was $229.2&nbsp;million, resulting primarily from consolidated net income adjusted for
	non-cash items of $182.9&nbsp;million, and a decrease in working capital of $46.3&nbsp;million. The decrease in working capital for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was primarily caused by
	improved efficiency in accounts receivable
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	54
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=55,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=657897,FOLIO='54',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DQ74301A.;10',USER='VRIVERA',CD='26-FEB-2016;06:14' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ74301_1_55">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	collections
	and an increase in income taxes payable caused, in part by, additional withholding taxes on repatriated funds. The time elapsed between the date customer orders are taken, deposits from
	the customers are received, and our receipt of full payments for the orders can fluctuate significantly from period to period. This cycle had a significantly positive effect on our free cash flow
	generation in 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, net cash provided by operating activities was $114.3&nbsp;million, which resulted primarily from consolidated net income adjusted for
	non-cash items of $153.6&nbsp;million, partially offset by an increase in working capital of $39.3&nbsp;million. The increase in working capital for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was
	primarily due to a decrease in customer advances as the timing between receipt of customer acceptances, such as obtaining acceptance during the year on a 21 Tesla high-field magnet in the Bruker
	BioSpin Group and completion of certain orders in the BEST Segment which had relatively large customer advances, and advance payments on new orders received, varied. In addition, there was an increase
	in accounts receivable caused by higher shipment levels towards the end of the fourth quarter of 2014. These uses of cash were partially offset by cash generated through an increase in accounts
	payable driven by improved vendor payment practices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net cash used in investing activities was $102.4&nbsp;million, compared to net cash used in investing activities of
	$201.9&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Cash used in investing activities during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was primarily caused by purchases, net of
	maturities, of short-term investments of $40.7&nbsp;million, capital expenditures of $34.2&nbsp;million and cash paid for acquisitions, net of cash acquired of $28.6&nbsp;million. Cash used in
	investing activities during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was primarily caused by purchases, net of maturities, of short-term investments of $192.6&nbsp;million and capital expenditures of
	$33.8&nbsp;million, partially offset by proceeds from the sale of product lines of $25.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	expect capital expenditures in 2016 to amount to approximately $50&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net cash used in financing activities was $168.0&nbsp;million, compared to net cash provided by financing activities of
	$6.7&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Cash used in financing activities during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was primarily caused by the repayment of the
	revolving line of credit from the proceeds of the repatriation of certain non U.S. cash, net of additional proceeds of $87.5&nbsp;million, and repurchases of common stock of $90.0&nbsp;million,
	partially offset by the issuance of common stock in connection with stock option exercises of $10.8&nbsp;million. Cash provided by financing activities during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	was primarily caused by proceeds of $7.9&nbsp;million from the issuance of common stock in connection with stock option exercises, partially offset by repayment of debt of $0.8&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	May 2015, our Board of Directors approved a share repurchase program (the "Anti-Dilutive Repurchase Program") under which we were authorized to repurchase our common stock in amounts
	intended to approximately offset, on an annual basis, the dilutive effect of shares that are, or may be, issued pursuant to option or restricted stock awards under our 2010 Incentive Compensation
	Plan. A total of 1,245,000 shares were repurchased at an aggregate cost of $24.9&nbsp;million prior to the suspension of the Anti-Dilutive Repurchase Program in November 2015, as discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	November 2015, our Board of Directors suspended the Anti-Dilutive Repurchase Program until January&nbsp;1, 2017 and approved an additional share repurchase program (the "Repurchase
	Program") under which repurchases of common stock in the amount of up to $225&nbsp;million may occur from time to time, in amounts, at prices, and at such times as we deem appropriate, subject to
	market conditions, legal requirements and other considerations. A total of 2,837,042 shares were repurchased at an
	aggregate cost of $65.0&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 under this Repurchase Program. The Repurchase Program will continue in 2016 and we intend to fund any additional repurchases from
	cash on hand, future cash flows from operations and available borrowings under our revolving credit facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	55
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=56,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=440406,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DQ74301A.;10',USER='VRIVERA',CD='26-FEB-2016;06:14' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ74301_1_56">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	repurchased shares are reflected within Treasury stock in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
	2015, we repatriated $235.3&nbsp;million of foreign earnings to the United States prompted by adverse interest rate conditions in Europe that were unfavorably impacting cash
	balances. No incremental U.S. income tax was incurred as the majority of the repatriation was comprised of previously taxed income and we had sufficient U.S. net operating losses and tax credits to
	offset any remaining tax liability. We used $129.5&nbsp;million of the repatriated funds to repay our outstanding balance on the revolving credit line under the Amended Credit Agreement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash,
	cash equivalents and short-term investments at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 totaled $468.3&nbsp;million and $497.5&nbsp;million, respectively, of which
	$420.9&nbsp;million and $460.7&nbsp;million, respectively, related to cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments held outside of the U.S. in our foreign subsidiaries, most significantly in
	the Netherlands and Switzerland.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	regularly evaluate our assertion that our foreign earnings are indefinitely reinvested. If the cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments held by our foreign subsidiaries are
	needed to fund operations in the U.S., or we otherwise elect to repatriate the unremitted earnings of our foreign subsidiaries in the form of dividends or otherwise, or if the shares of the
	subsidiaries were sold or transferred, we would likely be subject to additional U.S. income taxes, net of the impact of any available tax credits, which could result in a higher effective tax rate in
	the future. Based on our current plans and anticipated cash needs to fund our U.S. operations, it is our current intent to indefinitely reinvest all unremitted foreign earnings, that have not been
	previously taxed by the U.S., in our foreign subsidiaries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	May 2011, we entered into an amendment to, and restatement of, our then existing credit agreement, referred to as the Amended Credit Agreement. The Amended Credit Agreement provided a
	maximum commitment on our revolving credit line of $250.0&nbsp;million and a maturity date of May 2016. Borrowings under the revolving credit line of the Amended Credit Agreement accrued interest,
	at our option, at either (a)&nbsp;the greater of (i)&nbsp;the prime rate, (ii)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50% and (iii)&nbsp;adjusted LIBOR plus 1.00% or (b)&nbsp;LIBOR, plus margins
	ranging from 0.80% to 1.65%. There was also a facility fee ranging from 0.20% to 0.35%. The Amended Credit Agreement was repaid in full in October 2015, as noted above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	October&nbsp;27, 2015, we entered into a new revolving credit agreement, referred to as the 2015 Credit Agreement, and terminated the Amended Credit Agreement. The 2015 Credit
	Agreement provides a maximum commitment on the Company's revolving credit line of $500&nbsp;million and a maturity date of October 2020. Borrowings under the revolving credit line of the 2015 Credit
	Agreement accrue interest, at the Company's option, at either (a)&nbsp;the greater of (i)&nbsp;the prime rate, (ii)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50% and (iii)&nbsp;adjusted LIBOR plus
	1.00%, plus margins ranging from 0.00% to 0.30% or (b)&nbsp;LIBOR, plus margins ranging from 0.90% to 1.30%. There is also a facility fee ranging from 0.10% to 0.20%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Borrowings
	under the 2015 Credit Agreement are secured by guarantees from certain material subsidiaries, as defined in the 2015 Credit Agreement. The 2015 Credit Agreement also requires
	the Company to maintain certain financial ratios related to maximum leverage and minimum interest coverage (as defined in the 2015 Credit Agreement). Specifically, the Company's leverage ratio cannot
	exceed 3.5 and the Company's interest coverage ratio cannot be less than 2.5. In addition to the financial ratios, the 2015 Credit Agreement contains negative covenants, including among others,
	restrictions on liens, indebtedness of the Company and its subsidiaries, asset sales, dividends and transactions with affiliates. Failure to comply with any of these restrictions or covenants may
	result in an event of default under the terms of the 2015 Credit Agreement, which could permit acceleration of the debt and require the Company to prepay the debt before its scheduled due date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	56
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=57,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=633257,FOLIO='56',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DQ74301A.;10',USER='VRIVERA',CD='26-FEB-2016;06:14' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ74301_1_57">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we were in compliance with the covenants of the 2015 Credit Agreement. Our leverage ratio (as defined in the 2015 Credit Agreement) was 1.0 and our
	interest coverage ratio (as defined in the 2015 Credit Agreement) was 14.9.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had outstanding debt totaling $266.7&nbsp;million, consisting of $240.0&nbsp;million outstanding under the Note Purchase Agreement described below,
	$25.0&nbsp;million outstanding under the revolving loan component of the 2015 Credit Agreement described above and $1.7&nbsp;million under capital lease obligations and other loans. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, we had outstanding debt totaling $355.0&nbsp;million, consisting of $240.0&nbsp;million outstanding under the Note Purchase Agreement described below,
	$112.5&nbsp;million outstanding under the revolving loan component of the Amended Credit Agreement described above and $2.5&nbsp;million under capital lease obligations and other loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following is a summary of the maximum commitments and net amounts available to the Company as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 (dollars in millions):
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	lines of credit are with various financial institutions located primarily in Germany and Switzerland. The Company's other revolving lines of credit are unsecured and are typically
	due upon demand with interest payable monthly.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	January 2012, we entered into a note purchase agreement, referred to as the Note Purchase Agreement, with a group of accredited institutional investors. Under the Note Purchase
	Agreement we issued and sold $240.0&nbsp;million of senior notes, which consist of the following:
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$20.0&nbsp;million 3.16% Series&nbsp;2012A senior notes due January&nbsp;18, 2017;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$15.0&nbsp;million 3.74% Series&nbsp;2012A senior notes due January&nbsp;18, 2019;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$105.0&nbsp;million 4.31% Series&nbsp;2012A senior notes due January&nbsp;18, 2022; and
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$100.0&nbsp;million 4.46% Series&nbsp;2012A senior notes due January&nbsp;18, 2024.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
	the terms of the Note Purchase Agreement, we may issue and sell additional senior notes up to an aggregate principal amount of $600&nbsp;million, subject to certain conditions.
	Interest on the Senior Notes is payable semi-annually on January&nbsp;18 and July&nbsp;18 of each year. The Senior Notes are unsecured obligations of us and are fully and unconditionally
	guaranteed by certain of our direct and indirect subsidiaries. The Senior Notes rank pari passu in right of repayment with our other senior unsecured indebtedness. We may prepay some or all of the
	Senior Notes at any time in an amount not less than 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes to be prepaid, at a price equal to the sum of (a)&nbsp;100% of the principal
	amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, and (b)&nbsp;the applicable make-whole amount, upon not less than 30 and no more than 60&nbsp;days written notice to the holders of the Senior
	Notes. In the event of a change in control of the Company, as defined in the Note Purchase Agreement, we may be required to prepay the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof,
	plus accrued and unpaid interest.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Note Purchase Agreement contains affirmative covenants, including, without limitation, maintenance of corporate existence, compliance with laws, maintenance of insurance and
	properties, payment of taxes, addition of subsidiary guarantors and furnishing notices and other information. The Note Purchase Agreement also contains certain restrictive covenants that restrict our
	ability to, among
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	57
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=58,EFW="2227490",CP="BRUKER CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=112543,FOLIO='57',FILE='DISK125:[15ZCW1.15ZCW74301]DQ74301A.;10',USER='VRIVERA',CD='26-FEB-2016;06:14' -->
<A NAME="A2227490Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ74301_1_58">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227490Z10-K_HTM_BG74301A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	other
	things, incur liens, transfer or sell assets, engage in certain mergers and consolidations and enter into transactions with affiliates. The Note Purchase Agreement also includes customary
	representations and warranties and events of default. In the case of an event of default arising from specified events of bankruptcy or insolvency, all outstanding Senior Notes will become due and
	payable immediately without further action or notice. In the case of payment events of defaults, any holder of Senior Notes affected thereby may declare all Senior Notes held by it due and payable
	immediately. In the case of any other event of default, a majority of the holders of the Senior Notes may declare all the Senior Notes to be due and payable immediately. Pursuant to the Note Purchase
	Agreement, so long as any Senior Notes are outstanding we will not permit (i)&nbsp;our leverage ratio, as determined pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement, as of the end of any fiscal quarter to
	exceed 3.50 to 1.00, (ii)&nbsp;our interest coverage ratio as determined pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement as of the end of any fiscal quarter for any period of four consecutive fiscal
	quarters to be less than 2.50 to 1 or (iii)&nbsp;priority debt at any time to exceed 25% of consolidated net worth, as determined pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we were in compliance with the covenants of the Note Purchase Agreement. Our leverage ratio (as defined in the Note Purchase Agreement) was 1.0 and our
	interest coverage ratio (as defined in the Note Purchase Agreement) was 14.9.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had approximately $3.0&nbsp;million of net operating loss carryforwards available to reduce state taxable income; approximately $42.4&nbsp;million
	of German Trade Tax net operating losses that are carried forward indefinitely; and $42.9&nbsp;million of other foreign net operating losses that are expected to expire at various times beginning in
	2018. We also had U.S. federal tax credits of approximately $27.8&nbsp;million available to offset future tax liabilities that expire at various dates, which include research and development tax
	credits of $14.0&nbsp;million expiring at various times through 2034, foreign tax credits of $13.8&nbsp;million expiring at various times through 2024, and state research and development tax
	credits of $7.1&nbsp;million. Utilization of these credits and state net operating losses may be subject to annual limitations due to the ownership percentage change limitations provided by the
	Internal Revenue Code Section&nbsp;382 and similar state provisions. In the event of a deemed change in control under Internal Revenue Code Section&nbsp;382, an annual limitation on the
	utilization of net operating losses and credits may result in the expiration of all or a portion of the net operating loss and credit carryforwards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Uncertain
	tax contingencies are positions taken or expected to be taken on an income tax return that may result in additional payments to tax authorities. The total amount of uncertain
	tax contingencies is included in the "1-3 Years" column of the table below as we are not able to reasonably estimate the timing of potential future payments. If a tax authority agrees with the tax
	position taken or expected to be taken or the applicable statute of limitations expires, then additional payments will not be necessary.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	58
</FONT>
</P>
